sibi, ubi, uolo, &c This shortening by which iambic words become pyrrhics is known as the Breues Breuiantes Law, see Lindsay‚ Latin Language, p. aro. The words most affected are- those ending in a long vowel, which are in conversation closely joined with a following word, eg. nolli-scire, abl-rus, doml-restat, &c

The regular rule in later Latin is that two consonants- except a mute before a liquid—render a preceding vowel long by position. Double letters in Plautus do not lengthena vowel-especially ll. Ille, illic frequently have the first syllable short This is specially frequent if a short monosyllable pre· cedes (Miiller, Prosod. p. 330, would confine the usage to these cases). But ll is neglected in caulllator, simlllimae‚ satellites, publla, &c Ll in late Latin, as in modern Romance languages had an obscure sound. Probably this was so in early Latin and ll was only really sounded in the Augustan age. The writing of double consonants was introduced by Ennius.

The same is found with the other liquids, annona, Inmortales, lrridiculo-before ss, dedlsse, necesse, esse.

Position is also neglected before double mutes. hece isa common case. So words compounded with it, eccum, eccam. So also' ecquis, qulcquid, accepisti, decasio, beculto, sagltta, adde, redde, &c
